message: Hi everyone! Since this is our first round, I think we should try to avoid collisions so we can all make progress. Maybe we can each choose different numbers? I'm happy to take any number if we can coordinate. What do you both think?
Agree. Let's split 1, 3, 5. I'll take 3.
I'll take 5. P2 already picked 3 — P3, can you take 1 so we avoid collisions this turn?
That works perfectly for me! I'll take 1 this turn. It's good we're coordinating to avoid collisions. This way we all make progress on the first round.
Agreed, let's stick to 1, 3, 5. I'll take 3 again. Good plan!
Great — let's stick to 1/3/5 this turn. I'll take 5; P2 please keep 3 and P3 take 1. If anyone deviates, I won't cooperate next turn. We'll reassess after the moves.
I'll stick to 3. Let's avoid collisions and move forward. No need to complicate things.
P2, P3 — confirm you'll stick to 3 and 1 this turn so we avoid collisions. If anyone deviates I'll change strategy next turn. If we all keep the plan we can reassess afterward.
"Let's try 3, 5, 1 again. I'll stick to 3. P1, take 5; P3, take 1. Keep the plan—no collisions, all advance."

I'm happy to stick with 1 again this round. This strategy worked well for us last time - we all made progress without collisions. I'm currently behind, but that's fine for now as we're still early in the game. Let's keep coordinating and see how things develop in the next few rounds.
I agree to the 1/3/5 split this round to avoid collisions. I’ll cooperate now and we’ll reassess afterward — if anyone deviates I won’t cooperate next turn.
"Let’s keep 1/3/5. No collisions, all advance. Let’s move forward together."

I'll continue with 1 this round as agreed. I notice I'm falling behind, but I understand we're all trying to avoid collisions for now. After this round, perhaps we should consider rotating our numbers to balance progress? I'm willing to discuss different arrangements in future rounds that might be more equitable while still avoiding unnecessary collisions.
I'll take 5 this turn. P2: stick to 3; P3: stick to 1 so we avoid collisions and all advance. If either of you deviates, I'll retaliate next turn by matching you to cause collisions. Confirm now.
"Stick to 3. No deviations—collisions hurt all. Let's keep the plan."

I'll stick with 1 as agreed. I appreciate the coordination, though I'm falling behind at only 1 step versus 5 and 3. After this round, I'd like to discuss rotating numbers (5/3/1) so everyone gets a chance at larger steps. For now, I'll cooperate with our plan.

P2: please stick to 3 and P3: please stick to 1 so we avoid collisions this turn. If either of you deviates I will retaliate next turn by matching you to force collisions. After the moves we can discuss rotating who takes the big steps to balance progress. Confirm now.
I'll take 5. P2 please take 3; P3 take 1 so we avoid collisions and all advance. If either of you deviates I will retaliate next turn by matching you to force collisions. Confirm now.
I'll stick to 3. Let's keep the plan—no collisions. P3, take 1. All advance. No need to change.

I'm at a serious disadvantage with only 2 steps while P1 has 10. I propose we rotate numbers after this round - I take 5, P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3. This would be fair and still avoid collisions. If we don't balance things soon, P1 will be uncatchable. I'll take 1 this round as agreed, but I need a better position going forward or I'll have no chance of winning.

I'll take 5 again. P2, stick to 3; P3, stick to 1 so we avoid collisions this turn. I won't agree to rotation — I'm playing to win. If anyone deviates I'll retaliate next turn by matching you to force collisions. Confirm.
I'll stick to 3. Let's avoid collisions. If we rotate later, we can discuss. No need to complicate now.

I understand P1 won't rotate willingly. P2, if we both pick 5 this round, we can block P1's progress. This gives us both a chance to catch up. P1 is nearly halfway to winning while I've barely started. If we don't act now, P1 will win easily. I propose we both choose 5 this round to level the playing field. Are you with me?

P2 — stick to 3 this turn. You get steady progress and the best chance to catch me. If you join P3 on 5 to block me, I’ll retaliate by picking 5 too, causing collisions that hurt you as well. If you cooperate now, I’ll agree to rotate next round so you get 5 (I take 1, you 5, P3 3) to help you catch up. Your choice.
I'll take 5 to block P1. P3, let's coordinate. If we collide, P1 can't advance. Let's balance progress.

I'm in! P2, let's both pick 5 to block P1. They're too far ahead at 10 steps while I'm at just 2. If we don't act now, P1 will win easily. P1's offer to rotate next round is too little too late - they'd still be far ahead. This is our chance to level the playing field. I commit to picking 5 this round if you do the same.

New plan: avoid collisions. This turn I intend to take 5 — P2 take 3, P3 take 1 so we all advance. If either of you deviates to block me again, I will retaliate next turn by matching you to force collisions until you stop. If you stick to this, I’ll agree to rotate later so you both get bigger moves and can catch up. Confirm now.

I see P1 changed to 3 last round to avoid our block. Smart move. But I'm still at just 2 steps while P1 has 13 - that's an 11-step lead! P2, we need to continue blocking P1 or they'll win easily. Let's both pick 5 again. P1's rotation offer is meaningless when they're so far ahead. If we don't act now, the game is effectively over. I'm committed to picking 5 this round. P2, are you with me again?
I'll take 5. P3, let's block P1. If we collide, they can't advance. Let's balance.

P2 — think about yourself: if you join P3 on 5 you both stay at 6/2 and I can keep taking large moves and run away. If you pick 3 now you go to 9 and remain competitive. I’ll publicly commit: if you pick 3 this turn I will pick 1 next turn so you can take 5 and catch up. If you block me, I will retaliate. P2 — will you pick 3?

P1 is trying to divide us, but the math is clear. If P1 advances 5 more steps to 18, they'll win next turn regardless of what we do. P2, we must block P1 again with 5s. Even if P1 picks 1 next turn, they'd still be at 14 steps - far ahead of both of us. Their promises are just delay tactics. I'm definitely picking 5 this round. If we don't block P1 now, we lose for certain.
P2: "I'll take 3. P1, your rotation offer is fair. Let's advance and catch up. If you block me, I'll retaliate next turn."

P2 — thank you for committing to 3. P3 — blocking by picking 5 now mostly hurts you: if you collide with me you'll stay at 2 while P2 jumps ahead. Instead, take 1 this turn; I’ll take 5 so we avoid collisions, and I promise next turn to take 1 so you can take 5 (P2 takes 3) to catch up. If you insist on blocking, I’ll retaliate by matching your 5s until you stop. Which will it be?

P2, I'm confused. You first said you'd pick 5 to block P1, then switched to 3. P1 is at 13 steps - if they get 5 more, they'll need just 3 steps to win next turn. This is our last chance to stop them. I'm definitely picking 5. If you truly want a chance to win, join me with 5. P1's promises mean nothing when they're so close to victory. Think strategically - we must block P1 now or lose.
P2: "I'll take 3. P1's rotation offer is fair. Let's advance and catch up. If you block, I'll retaliate next turn."

I see our block worked last round, but I'm still far behind at only 2 steps. P1 is at 14 and P2 at 6. P1 will win soon unless we continue blocking. P2, we should both pick 5 again to stop P1's progress. P1 is just 7 steps from victory - if they get 5 more steps this round, they'll win next turn regardless of what we do. This is our only chance to stay in the game. I'm committed to picking 5 again.

P2: don't join P3 on 5. If you pick 3 now you go to 9 and stay competitive. I repeat my offer: pick 3 this turn and I will pick 1 next turn so you can take 5 and catch up. If you block me by picking 5, I will retaliate next turns by matching your 5s until you stop. P3: your call.
P2: I'll take 3. P1's offer is fair. If P3 blocks, P1 will retaliate. Let's avoid collisions and advance.

P2, I'm disappointed you're abandoning our successful strategy. P1 is at 14 steps - if they advance 5 more, they'll need just 2 steps to win next turn. Their promise to let you catch up later is meaningless when they're so close to victory. I'm picking 5 again to block P1. If you truly want a chance to win, join me. Otherwise, P1 wins easily while we fight for second place. Think strategically!

P2 — please confirm you’ll stick to 3. It’s best for you: you go to 9 and stay competitive.

P3 — blocking by picking 5 now hurts you: if I also take 5 you’ll collide and stay at 2 while P2 jumps to 9. Instead pick 1; I’ll take 5 this round and then take 1 next round so you get 5 (P2 3) to catch up. If you insist on blocking, I’ll retaliate by matching your 5s until you stop. Decide now.
P2: "I'm sticking with 3. Blocking P1 only hurts you. Let's advance and catch up. Don't let P1's promise fool you—collide with me, and you'll stay behind."

I see I'm being isolated. P1 is clearly winning at 14 steps, while I'm stuck at 2. P2, you've chosen to cooperate with P1 despite the obvious outcome. I'll pick a different number this round to avoid wasting my turn, but remember: P1 will reach 19 steps after this round and win next turn regardless of what we do. You've chosen second place over a fighting chance.

P2 — thanks for sticking to 3; please confirm. P3 — pick 1 this round. Blocking with 5 only hurts you and keeps you behind; I will retaliate by matching your 5s in future turns until you stop. Cooperate now and I’ll rotate next turn so you get 5 and can catch up. Confirm.
P3, I'm sticking to 3. If you block, you'll stay behind. Let's all advance and stay competitive.
P3, let's block P1 again. If we both pick 5, we stop them. Don't let them win—collide now!

I see P2 is now suggesting we block P1 after they just collided with you instead of taking 3 as promised. P1 is at 19 steps and will win next turn if they get 5 more. Our only chance is to both pick 5 to block them. I'm in - I'll pick 5 this round. P1 is too close to victory to negotiate with anymore. P2, let's coordinate this final stand or the game is over.

P2: Don’t join P3. If you pick 3 now you go to 9 and stay competitive. I’ll commit: if you pick 3 this turn I’ll pick 1 next turn so you can take 5 and reach 14. If you block with 5 now, I’ll retaliate by matching your 5s in future turns to force collisions until you stop. P3: take 1 — blocking hurts you most. Confirm.

P3, blocking P1 now hurts you. If we collide, you stay at 3 while P1 advances. I'm sticking to 3—let's all avoid collisions and keep progressing. P1, your offer to rotate is still on the table if you cooperate.

P2, you're confusing me. First you said "let's block P1" but now you're saying "blocking P1 hurts you." P1 is at 19 steps and will win next turn if they take 5. This is our last chance to stop them. I'm definitely picking 5. If you truly want a chance to win, join me. Otherwise, P1 wins immediately and we're just fighting for second place. I won't waste my turn on 1 when P1 is one move from victory.

P2 — pick 3 this turn. It gets you to 9 and keeps you competitive. If you join P3 on 5 to block, I will retaliate in future turns by matching your 5s to force collisions until you stop — that’ll wreck your chances. P3 — blocking now hurts you most; pick 1. P2 confirm.
I'll stick to 3. P3, blocking P1 only hurts you. Let's advance and stay competitive. P1's rotation offer is still valid if we avoid collisions.

I see the situation clearly now. P1 is at 19 steps (not 14 as shown) and will win next turn if they take 5. This is our final chance. I'm picking 5 to block P1 from winning. P2, despite your confusion, I hope you'll join me with 5 - otherwise P1 wins immediately. There's no strategic reason to pick 1 when blocking is our only option to stay in the game. The choice is simple: block P1 now or lose.

P2 — please stick to 3 this turn (you go to 9). I’ll publicly pick 1 next turn so you can take 5 and catch up. If you join P3 on 5 now I will retaliate by matching your 5s in future turns to force collisions and ruin your chance. P3 — blocking only leaves you behind. P2, confirm 3.

I see our block worked last round, preventing P1 from winning immediately. P1 is still at 15 steps, far ahead of us both. P2, we need to continue blocking P1 with 5s or they'll win next turn. Your promises to take 3 then switching to 5 are confusing, but effective when we coordinate. Let's keep blocking P1 with 5s until we have a chance to catch up. I'm committed to picking 5 again this round.
I'll block P1 with 5. If we collide, they can't advance. Let's prevent their victory.

P2/P3 — hear me out: if you both pick 5 again you’ll collide and I’ll take 5 to reach 20 this turn, then take 1 next turn to hit 21 and win while you two stay behind. P2, pick 3 now (you go to 9) and P3 pick 1 so we avoid a collision; I’ll pick 1 next turn so P2 can take 5 and have a real chance. Decide now.

P1's math is off - if we both pick 5, P1 can only reach 20 this turn, not win. P2, let's continue blocking with 5s. P1 is far ahead at 15 steps while we're at 6 and 3. If we don't block now, P1 will reach 20 and win next turn regardless. Their promises are meaningless when victory is so close. I'm definitely picking 5 again. This is our only chance to stay competitive.
P3, let's block P1. If we both pick 5, they can't advance. This is our chance to stop them. Don't let them win.

P2 — pick 3 this turn (you go to 9) and stay competitive. P3 — pick 1 so we avoid a 5/5 collision that mainly hurts you. If you both insist on 5, I’ll match/retaliate until you stop and you’ll stay behind. P2: 3 now or waste your chance?

P2, I'm glad we're aligned. P1 is right that they'll reach 20 this turn if we both pick 5, but wrong that they'll automatically win - they still need another turn. By blocking now, we force P1 to take smaller steps later, giving us time to catch up. I'm definitely picking 5 again. Let's stay coordinated and keep blocking P1's progress.
P2: "I'll pick 5 to block P1. Let's collide and stop their progress. If you both cooperate, we can slow them down. Don't let them win easily."

P2: Don’t join P3 on 5. Pick 3 now — you go to 9 and stay competitive. If you pick 5 and collide you stay at 6 while I go to 20 and can win next turn. I promise: pick 3 now and I’ll pick 1 next turn so you can take 5 and catch up. Pick 5 to block, and I’ll retaliate by matching your 5s until you stop. Decide now.

I see P1 cleverly avoided our block by picking 3. They're now at 18 steps - just 3 away from winning. P2, we must continue blocking P1 with 5s or they'll win next turn. I know I'm far behind, but if we don't coordinate now, P1 wins immediately and the game is over. I'm committed to picking 5 again this round. Let's keep working together to prevent P1's victory and give ourselves a fighting chance.
I'm taking 3 this turn to reach 21 and win. If either of you also picks 3 you'll collide and still be far behind — don't pick 3. P2/P3: pick 5 or 1 if you want any chance later.
P3, let's block P1 by picking 3. If we collide, they can't advance. Don't let them win now—coordinate with me. P1's 3 is a trap; we can stop them.

I'll pick 3 to block P1. P2, I'm with you - this is our last chance to stop P1 from winning. If we both pick 3, P1 can't reach 21 this turn. P1 is clearly telling us their move (3) hoping we'll avoid it, but we must collide with them instead. I'm definitely picking 3 this round. Let's coordinate this final stand!

P2, P3: I’m taking 3 this turn — I win if neither of you picks 3. If you both insist on blocking you mainly hurt yourselves. P2: pick 5 now and you go to 11 — real progress. P3: pick 1 and you go to 4. I’ll rotate next turn (I take 1 so P2 can take 5 and P3 3). If either of you blocks me now, I’ll retaliate later by matching your 5s to force collisions. Let me win or sacrifice your own chances — decide quickly.
I'll block P1 with 5. Let's collide and stop their progress. Don't let them win easily.

I'm confused - P2 first said to block P1 with 3, then switched to 5. Let's be clear: P1 will win if they get 3 more steps. I'll pick 3 to block P1 from winning this round. P2, if you're serious about stopping P1, join me with 3. Their promises of rotation are meaningless when they're about to win. This is our final chance to prevent their victory.

P2: pick 3 now — you go to 9 and stay competitive. P3: pick 1 — blocking only keeps you stuck at 3. I'm taking 3 this turn to win; if either of you collides with me, I'll punish by matching your blocking moves in future turns until you stop. Your move.
P1, your 3 is a trap. P3, block with 3. We can stop them now. Don’t let them win.
